Dear Ms. Koerber:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
February 3, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program
managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
Two of twenty-five personnel records reviewed lacked current, or updated
tuberculosis screening completed timely.
Repeat Violation Established
2021 Renewal, CAP approved 2/9/21
2020 Interim, CAP approved 11/24/20
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for
new employees.
Job shadowing shall not be the only form of orientation.
The orientation shall include the following:
(a) The institution's purpose, policies, and procedures,
including discipline, crisis intervention techniques,
and emergency and safety procedures.
One of nineteen new personnel files reviewed did not have evidence of the
orientation taking place.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions.
updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an updated treatment plan for each resident at
least once every 90-calendar days following the
initial treatment plan.
Two of three open youth case files reviewed did not have the updated treatment plan
completed as required each 90-days.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Change the objectives when accomplished and address new objectives for the
goal.
 Develop realistic timeframes for each goal.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Add the period under review to the beginning of each treatment plan.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2021 Renewal Inspection.
There were no special investigations during this period under review.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
This report documents the facility’s effort to follow through with their corrective action
plan from the 2021 renewal licensing inspection. The Chief Administrator (CA) was
able to identify the issues with the TB testing and the facility is in the process of
developing a new system. A discussion involved the CA making changes in the
corrective action plan if they find their efforts are not providing the results they had
envisioned.
Interviews:
Staff were interviewed and all presented with a strong desire to engage in best
practice with the youth. They also felt supported by management. All the youth were
observed to be engaged in different activities at the time of the onsite inspection and
staff were very attentive to the youth.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules requirements. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective
action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
